Award.AwardTitle: Behavioral and neural bases of the perception of facial expressions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Effective social communication and interaction rely on accurately detecting and interpreting the facial expressions of others. Facial expressions can convey many things, including emotions, attitudes, and intentions, and errors in interpreting the meaning of facial expressions are relatively common. These errors can be costly, given that accurate interpretation is critical in many different contexts. For example, it is important when establishing relationships with others, or for those who have to make quick judgments of intent (e.g., security agents). Dr. Paula Niedenthal and colleagues (University of Wisconsin at Madison) investigate the behavioral and neural processes that individuals use to interpret the meanings of the facial expressions they see in their social world. Their research focuses on the smile because of its fundamental role in guiding social interaction. While folk wisdom holds that smiles signal happy feelings, everyday experience and research findings document the extreme complexity of this expression. Niedenthal and colleagues propose a social-function typology. They hold that there exist three physically and dynamically distinct smiles that evolved to solve basic tasks of social living. The tasks include 1) rewarding the behavior of self and other (reward smiles), 2) creating social bonds (affiliative smiles), and 3) negotiating social hierarchies (dominance smiles). How, then, do individuals arrive at an accurate interpretation of a given smile, and why do inaccuracies sometimes occur, especially in cross-cultural interactions?

Niedenthal and colleagues will study the roles of two social behaviors, eye contact and facial mimicry, in the process of interpreting smiles. Eye contact is hypothesized to be a trigger of facial mimicry, facilitating the reproduction of the perceived smile on the perceiver's own face. Facial mimicry, consistent with recent "embodied emotion" theories of emotional information processing is hypothesized to yield a simulation of a corresponding affective state, which provides sufficient information for the accurate interpretation of the smile. The neural bases of these social behaviors, as well as the role of other neural systems in creating the "feeling" of a smile in the perceiver of the smile, will be tested in neuroimaging studies. Finally, the central role of culture in moderating the tendency to achieve eye contact and to engage in facial mimicry will be explored.

This research promises to advance the theory and techniques that scientists use to conduct research on human facial expression, and on the ways in which an individual's behavior and brain work together to decode facial expressions, including but not limited to the smile. Undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Wisconsin at Madison will work, in teaching and laboratory settings, to advance these ideas. A number of clinical conditions, including autism, schizophrenia, and Parkinson's disease, are associated with striking deficits in interpreting facial expression of emotion. Understanding of these populations will be facilitated by the insights from this research, and new relationships, such as those between humans and robots, will be informed. Finally, as the most frequent and the most rewarding facial expression, the smile is critical in all international relations. Cultural relativity in interpreting the smile, revealed in the present investigations, will promote greater understanding among the world's peoples.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From workshops designed to teach people in international business how to smile, through a Smile Campaign to attract tourists to Paris, to the use of smiles in US marketing strategies, billions of dollars have been spent on the human smile. And yet, the science of the smile has been constrained by the intuition that the smile (when not “faked”) is merely, and always, the outward expression of positive emotion. To motivate a deeper understanding of the human smile we started by asking, what are smiles for? Social-functional theories hold that facial expressions have evolved to regulate social interaction. For instance, anger expressions signal that a person believes her welfare is threatened, and perceivers of the expression can adjust their behavior accordingly (e.g., correct an injustice). Smiles are the most frequent facial expressions in many cultures, but they actually occur during a variety of emotional states – not only positive ones – and can accomplish multiple social tasks. Hypotheses central to the NSF-funded research were: (1) There are three functionally and physically distinct smile expressions, which have evolved to solve the basic social tasks of a) rewarding adaptive behavior (reward smiles), b) creating and maintaining social bonds (affiliation smiles), and c) negotiating social hierarchies (dominance smiles). (2) In order to accurately interpret (decode) smile meaning, people match their own faces and brains to the smile thereby creating in themselves an internal model (or simulation) of the emotion that is conveyed by the expression. (3) There are cultural differences in the degree to which the need arises to communicate reward, affiliation and dominance through facial expression, and also in the extent to which the simulation processes described in hypothesis 2 are used in the decoding of smiles.

Significant outcomes of the research:

(1)  We derived empirically-based descriptions of the physical appearance of reward, affiliation and dominance smiles. Based on these descriptions, we created videos of fifteen professional actors expressing each smile type (Figure 1). Evidence for the validity of the proposed typology was acquired in studies in which participants explicitly categorized and rated the meaning of the smiles. Further evidence was provided by studies in which machine learning was used to model how people mentally represent smile categories.

(2)   We documented the role of facial mimicry in interpreting smiles by comparing perceivers' ability to accurately decode smile meaning when their faces could produce facial mimicry and when mimicry was inhibited. In an experiment involving transcranium magnetic stimulation (TMS) we inhibited activity of distinct locations in motor cortex, somatosensory cortex, or a control neural center of experimental participants as they engaged in facial expression recognition tasks. Results supported a role for both cortical areas in interpreting facial expression, and provide evidence of how mimicry helps people decode the meaning of a perceived smile.

(3)   We investigated the culture construct of historical heterogeneity-homogeneity in several studies. Historical heterogeneity (versus homogeneity) of long-term migration means that a country or society has derived from the influx of many source countries (e.g., populations of Brazil has derived from many sources countries, while the population of Norway from very few). Findings revealed that historical heterogeneity is associated with a) greater pressures toward the use of reward and affiliation smiles, b) the possession of norms for expressing emotions rather than dissimulating them, and c) the production of facial expressions that are more easily decoded by individual from other cultures (i.e., cross-cultural decoding accuracy).

(4)  In translational research, we documented two significant implications of the simulation process. One project revealed that protracted pacifier use reduces the spontaneous occurrence of facial mimicry, and is associated with poorer emotional development outcomes, especially in boys. Other translational research investigated the implications of these processes for facial paralysis patients.
